NewsLine.NewsLineText: GERMANY-CONSERVATIVES (PICTURE):Merkel regains control of German conservatives

body.p: By Emma Thomasson and Clifford Coonan

BERLIN/MUNICH, Sept 23 (Reuters) - Germany's Angela Merkel, elbowed aside as conservative chancellor candidate by Bavaria's Edmund Stoiber, reclaimed her position as leading light of the opposition on Monday after the centre-right lost Sunday's vote.

Merkel, the leader of the Christian Democrats (CDU), which together with their Bavarian Christian Social Union allies chose Stoiber to lead the conservative election charge, said she also wanted to take over the parliamentary leadership of the party.

Friedrich Merz, the leader of the CDU in parliament for the last two years, said he had decided to make way for Merkel to avoid a power struggle, restoring the most senior women in German party politics as the main conservative mouthpiece.

Merkel's combined position as national leader and head of the parliamentary party puts her in a strong position to stand as a future conservative chancellor candidate, perhaps in the 2006 election, and weakens the hand of her rivals in the party.
"The election was a photo-finish and that shows that the conservatives are back. We will take on our opposition mandate with all force and strength," Merkel told a news conference.
"Opposition work will be better handled with a joint leadership of the parliamentary group and the party."

After Merkel stood aside in January to allow CSU head Stoiber to lead the conservative challenge to Social Democrat Chancellor Gerhard Schroeder, party insiders said she would be rewarded for her loyalty. Stoiber backed her move on Monday.
Her major rival in the party is Roland Koch, premier of the central state of Hesse, expected to flex his muscles in the conservatives now that Stoiber's bid failed.
STOIBER'S FUTURE UNCLEAR

It was not immediately clear whether Stoiber, criticised for failing to keep the focus of the campaign on Schroeder's handling of the stagnant economy, would pursue a role on the national stage or focus again on his role as Bavarian premier.

At a news conference in Munich, Stoiber predicted Schroeder's Social Democrats-Greens coalition, returned to power in Sunday's vote but with a much reduced majority, would fail and said he would wait in the wings to form a new government.

He told a news conference in Berlin later that he would contribute to parliamentary debates and travel abroad as CSU leader, starting with a trip to Washington to rebuild ties damaged by Schroeder's vocal opposition to a war against Iraq.

However, Stoiber stopped short of saying whether he would be available as chancellor candidate next time round. Helmut Kohl lost as conservative candidate in the 1976 election, but became chancellor in 1982 after linking up with the Free Democrats.

"The position of chancellor candidate ends with the election, of course. The CSU will remain a strong figure in the conservative alliance," Stoiber said, noting that the CSU's strong performance in Bavaria, where they won nearly 60 percent, had helped the right gain in the election.
But at 60, Stoiber might not get another chance, while Merkel, 48, could be at the peak of her powers in four years.

Merkel became the first woman leader of a major German party in April 2000 as the party Helmut Kohl led for quarter of a century tried to make a fresh start after the ex-chancellor admitted accepting about $1 million in secret party donations.
Then some admirers hailed her as a German Margaret Thatcher, a fellow scientist who led Britain's Conservatives out of opposition in the 1970s.

But Merkel, a liberal Protestant from the communist East, failed to impose discipline on a party dominated by practising Roman Catholics, most of them men, from west and south Germany, and saw many CDU rivals back Stoiber as chancellor candidate.

But since then the woman who only entered active politics in 1989, acting as spokeswoman for the short-lived democratic East German government that approved reunification, has been gradually building support in the party. The parliamentary leadership could give her a new springboard for power.

Born Angela Kasner in the northern port of Hamburg on July 17, 1954, her left-wing clergyman father moved his family to the Communist east soon after her birth. She takes her surname from her first husband, Ulrich Merkel, whom she divorced in 1982.
Bowing to party pressure, she married long-term partner Joachim Sauer, a chemistry professor, in 1998, shortly after becoming CDU general secretary. She has no children.
